title: ETHIOPIA
subtitle: Livelihoods dependent on rainfed agricultural production and small-scale farms threatened by changing climate

steps.theme: Livelihoods dependent on rainfed agricultural production and small-scale farms threatened by changing climate

steps.title: overview
steps.content:
Ethiopia is the fifth largest producer of maize in Africa. The vast majority of maize production in Ethiopia (94%) is done by smallholder farmers, nearly all of whom rely on seasonal rains to support their crops.

Ethiopia has two distinct rainy seasons and one dry season. The short rainy season, or belg, occurs from February to May and the long rainy season, or kiremt, from June through September.

Changes in the seasonal rains can greatly impact food security. In 2015, a late start to the short rains in some areas of the country forced many farmers to plant crops more suited for a shorter growing season instead of maize, limiting output of a vital food source, and reducing the resilience of smallholder farmers to future challenges.

steps.title: livelihoods
steps.content: Where will maize production be impacted by climate variability?

steps.aside:
Livelihoods

Maize production

Ethiopia

Rainfed agriculture dominates the landscape in Ethiopia, encompassing nearly 49% of its total area.

steps.title: stressors  & shocks
steps.content: In which locations is maize production exposed to climate variability and shocks and what is the severity?

steps.aside:
stressors  & shocks

Maize production & variability in short rains

Ethiopia

49% of Ethiopia is used for rainfed agriculture

Rainfall during the short rains is declining at rates as high as 24% per decade in some maize-growing areas.

10% of the area currently used for maize production has been impacted by this decrease.

stressors  & shocks

Maize production & variability in long rains

Ethiopia

49% of the land area of Ethiopia is used for rainfed agriculture

Rainfall during the long rains is declining at rates as high as 11% per decade in some maize-growing areas.

steps.title: vulnerability
steps.content: What factors affect the vulnerability of smallholder maize farmers to climate variability and shocks?

steps.aside:
Vulnerability

Fertility rates in maize production areas

Ethiopia

Fertility rates in maize producing areas are >5 children per woman.

The population of Ethiopia is projected to increase from 98,942,102 to 142,900,000 by 2030, creating further stress.

Source: International Futures (IFs) forecasting system and the Pardee Center for International Futures at the University of Denver.

Vulnerability

Mass media access in maize production areas

Ethiopia

In maize producing areas, more than 69% of women lack access to mass media.

Vulnerability

Illiteracy rate for women in maize production areas

Ethiopia

In maize producing areas, more than half of all women are illiterate.

steps.title: insights
steps.subtitle: agricultural livelihoods & climate change in ethiopia
steps.content:
Climatic changes in primary maize growing seasons will cause lower food production in areas with high sensitivity to changing precipitation patterns.

Access to information is critical to resilience of crop production. Further, without careful planning, the impact of interventions may be limited by high levels of illiteracy and lack of access to communications media, particularly among women.
